utterances: It was actually unanimous.
We both felt that Chana Joffe-Walt's story was the best story.
It was a tough decision.
But all three stories were interesting and well-done.
They're three excellent reporters, and I'll be very intrigued to hear which one the listeners like the most.
Christopher Turpin, executive producer of ALL THINGS CONSIDERED, thanks for the rare appearance.
Thanks, Robert.
It was a pleasure.
Okay.
Now, it's up to you, you listeners, now to either confirm or override the so-called professional judges.
You can hear the three Planet Money stories in full by going to npr.org, where you can also cast your vote on which one gets to be heard on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
Good morning.
Ever since Hurricane Katrina, people on the Gulf Coast have told us what they need most is insurance.
If they get affordable property insurance, they can rebuild.
If they don't, they can't.
That's why many people were stunned when St. Paul Travelers said it would not renew some commercial policies around New Orleans.
Now Louisiana wants to keep other insurance companies from abandoning the area.
NPR's Cheryl Corley reports.
For some companies, the deadline is less than three months away.
St. Paul Travelers says beginning in March it will stop renewing policies for a number of small and mid-size commercial properties.
A company spokeswoman did not want to be recorded, but said Travelers has a high concentration of those properties in hurricane-prone areas and needs to balance its risk.
Mark Drennen, the president of the Greater New Orleans Economic Group, calls Travelers' announcement a major blow.

This comes at a time when our businesses were already facing five, ten-time increases in their premiums, at a time when their deductibles were going from 500,000 to 10 million, or even worse in some cases, to all of a sudden have the number one carrier say, you know, we're not even going to be in this market anymore, is shocking.
It's not clear how many businesses will be affected, but state officials, worried that other commercial insurers might follow suit, convened a meeting in Baton Rouge.
Governor Kathleen Blanco says Louisiana wanted to give insurers an update on levee repairs, coastal restoration and other efforts designed to mitigate losses.
This is not an exclusive Louisiana situation, but ours is in a crisis mode.
This is going on in every coastal state.
Apparently the insurers have reassessed how much vulnerability they have to risk.
And they have overreacted, we believe.
But they're - you know, right now we're at their mercy.
The federal government has promised Louisiana nearly $6 billion for its hurricane protection efforts.
Almost a billion has been spent.
Louisiana also has new building codes.
Insurance commissioner James Donelon says this might actually be a good time for insurers to be in the market.
I point out to them that our structures in the metropolitan New Orleans, southeast and southwest Louisiana, have now been subjected to two storms of comparable size.
So that weak rooves(ph) - roofs, weak trees that were subject to being blown over and damaging properties - they're down, and those roofs are replaced.
We are a much better risk than we were a year and a half ago when these storms came ashore.
After the meeting, Jason Schupp, a vice president at Zurich Insurance, says his company will maintain its presence in New Orleans.
Zurich is the state's third largest commercial insurance provider, but Schupp says all insurers are in the process of rebalancing.
He says it's not just hurricanes and levees that's cause for concern, but also an increasing number of people and commercial properties in the Gulf Coast region.
We've had growth which has outrun our perception of the risk.
So what we're seeing now is some catching up, as we've had an extremely active two hurricane seasons - in 2004 and in 2005.
Louisiana Citizens Property Insurance, the state-sponsored insurer of last resort, would likely pick up coverage for many.
And there's worry that it could become overloaded.
So state officials are asking travelers to reconsider, and they've come up with a plan that increases Louisiana's citizen's coverage limits.
They want travelers to pick up customers who want even more.
Governor Blanco says that's one of many steps the state is taking as it tries to create a safe environment for businesses and a less risky one for insurers.
We'll pray all together that the weather holds, and that we have a few good years ahead of us, without stretching the insurers one more time and really sinking us.
Hi, there.
Go ahead.
Cori sent me a picture of this little girl named Evelyn, who had been horribly disfigured by the LRA.
She had been used as a shield.
I couldn't get this girl's image out of my head.
And I showed the picture to John and he said, you know, we've got to do this.
Let's just bring her over.
John is Eldin's husband, John Turteltaub, a motion picture director.
So we went to Uganda, and only by really going could we really understand the weight and the power and the extraordinary sorrow of what's going there.
It was there, in a Ugandan rehabilitation camp, that they met 15-year-old Evelyn.
Sitting in a caf√© in West Hollywood, she holds a napkin to her face, trying to hide the scars left by a bomb blast.
Her lips are barely there, and her speech is still affected.
But Evelyn is a survivor, thanks to a team of volunteer surgeons in Fort Wayne, Indiana who tended to her injuries.
That was last spring.
When we met her recently in Los Angeles, Evelyn was out on the town with the new friends who helped bring her to America.
Well, I went shopping today.
I bought earrings and glasses.
Evelyn is shy, but Cori Stern coaxes her into recalling the pain she suffered as a human shield for the LRA.
How many operations have you had?
I had two in Uganda.
And you have how many to go?
Six.
Stern says the Name Campaign wants to bring other Ugandan children to the U.S.
for medical treatment.
But she wonders if she can get Hollywood's attention for yet another African humanitarian crisis.
She is going to be a trendsetter when she goes back there.
That question's on the minds of eight women meeting on this night in John Turteltaub's Hollywood Hills home.
Ms. MELINDA RANGEY(ph) (Jewelry Maker): We want to talk about like her education and she wants to be a nurse when she grows up.
So now...
Melinda Rangey, a jewelry maker, says six months ago she knew next to nothing about Uganda's tragedy.
I was kind of one of those people that you don't relate to them on a human level.
You think, well, it's Africa.
It happens there a lot.
I didn't know such incredible strife is happening there until I met Amy and Cory and all the girls.
And I felt a greater responsibility to make it different.
From his backyard, John Turteltaub looks down on the lights of the city and likens each one to a suffering child in Uganda.
Many of their names are now engraved on gold and silver tags from the Name Campaign.
Turteltaub recently gave one to a well-known actor.
And I said, all right, quick, what's the name of the kid on your dogtag?
And he sort of looked at me; he only been thinking of it as a group and not really thinking of it as a kid.
And then the other day he sent me an e-mail and he said I've been thinking about - and he said the name of the kid, and he's very aware now of that kid's name.
That's kid's name, by the way, is Jacob.
Also inscribed on his tag are the words, speak their names, tell their stories, and bring them home.
For NPR News, I'm Phillip Martin.
It's Thursday and time to read from some of your e-mail.
And we don't want to rub salt in the wounds of Trojan fans, but we got a few letters about our preview of the Rose Bowl game.
In it, we said that USC was going for its third straight national championship.
Well, that didn't sit too well with some of our listeners.
Chris Layvak(ph) of Austin, Texas, felt we could have been more accurate.
He writes, `Two years ago, USC fell on the short end of the BCS selection process and missed out on playing in the national championship game, which was between LSU and Oklahoma.
While USC was a great team in 2003 and many felt they were robbed, the fact is LSU was the BCS champion and USC got named co-champion by way of the AP poll.'
